title: James Crossley (aka Hunter the Gladiator): my 40 fitness tips for the over-40s
text:
V oid of the slicked blonde hair and searing tan that made women of the 90â€™s swoon, you probably wouldnâ€™t recognise James â€˜Hunterâ€™ Crossley if you passed him in the street. Towering at 6'3", and wide â€“ so wide you can imagine he often has to dislodge himself from doorways â€“ the ex-Gladiators star boasts a colossal build thatâ€™s been 31 years in the making.
It all started with a marathon session of watching Rocky films, aged 12. From that point Crossley set forth on a goal-based fitness journey: with every year he aged, heâ€™d gain a stone and add an inch to his arm circumference.
His moment of fame came aged 19, when Crossley â€“ now sporting a whopping 19-inch arm and 19 stoneâ€™s worth of muscle mass â€“ was invited to take to the ring as Hunter in one of the most-watched TV shows of the 90â€™s . He ditched the inch-a-year vow and instead threw himself into the all-action series, which ran on British TV from 1992 to 2000. A spate of acting jobs and a US tour with the Peter Hall company followed.
Hunter greets members of the military at the Royal Tournament Credit: Richard Watt H owever, Crossley says that throughout this period in the limelight, fitness remained his priority. He recalls having a purpose-built gym installed underneath the Ahmanson Theatre in Los Angeles in which he would dead-lift to the rousing soliloquies of co-stars Rebecca Hall and Dan Stevens.
Then, in 2012, Crossley swapped his jazz shoes for trainers and established his own gym franchise, Chelsea Fitness. Now 43, he is determined to help over-40s get in shape. Family obligations, work pressures, aches and pains: there are no excuses for poor health. â€œThe keyâ€, Crossley says, â€œis to make sustainable life changes, not to seek quick fixesâ€.
â€˜Hunterâ€™ might not seem like the name of a man familiar with delayed gratification but Crossley certainly knows what heâ€™s talking about. Below, he presents his tips for those looking to get fit at forty.
1. Have a medical â€œWhen youâ€™re over forty," says Crossley, "you can arrange to have a medical check-up for free on the NHS. Theyâ€™ll run a range of tests and give you feedback specific to your bodyâ€™s needs.â€
2. Evaluate your current condition â€œItâ€™s important to be honest with yourself; test your limits but donâ€™t push them. Can you do a squat? Can you a run a mile? Or can you not even tie your shoelace? You need to know what stage youâ€™re at before you start pushing your body.â€
The five most ridiculous fitness trends ever 3. Make definite goals. â€œIâ€™m very goal orientated, which I think is very important when anyone is training or transforming their body. A race, an event, or maybe a specific weight-level: having something to work towards will help when your motivation lulls.â€
4. Warm-up is key â€œInstead of brushing over, it needs to be part of your plan. Iâ€™m guilty of skipping a warm-up due to sheer laziness but itâ€™s important to mobilise and stimulate your muscles before engaging in heavy exercise.
5. Perfect exercise form is essential â€œYou need to extend fully, no half-range motion.â€
6. Slow your tempo down â€œWhen youâ€™re younger, you lift heavy weights as quickly as possible. When youâ€™re older you want to be slow and deliberate to avoid causing any damage. If youâ€™ve got any shoulder problems or back problems youâ€™re only going to cause more damage.â€
7. More recovery time â€œYou need more recovery when youâ€™re over 40 than when youâ€™re 20, so if youâ€™re training hard, make sure you still have the recovery days. It doesnâ€™t mean you canâ€™t do something on these days. You could still do a speed walk but you donâ€™t want to be hammering the weights everyday.â€
8. Find activities you enjoy â€œItâ€™s the best way to ensure that you keep at your fitness plan.â€
9. Do a bit of everything â€œCombine strength-training with flexibility and cardio.â€
10. Keep exercise varied â€œIf you do the same exercises every week, your body can get stuck at certain planes. Every six weeks Iâ€™d suggest changing up your routine.
"They say as a kid you should play a variety of different sports so youâ€™re strengthening many different muscles. That shouldnâ€™t stop as you enter middle-age.â€
11. Look at exercise as a priority â€œSo many people will choose to go to the pub or will use their family as an excuse to skip the gym. Youâ€™ve got to prioritise exercise and fit it into your schedule.â€
12. Make people accountable â€œFind a gym buddy and hold each other accountable. If you plan to meet a friend at the gym at 6am, youâ€™re far less likely to flake and have a lay in. Likewise, if youâ€™ve booked a squash court or a gym class in advance, youâ€™re more likely to actually workout as youâ€™ve made that commitment in advance.â€
TRAINING PARTNERS # Training with partners can be an essential part on the path to achieve your chosen goals. # 1. You will be more motivated - creating accountability to not let people down.It will also ensure you turn up for regular sessions and form good habits. # 2. Workouts are more fun- loading and unloading bars alone can be tiresome, plus people can find certain exercise boring , the mind can wonder off track .With good partners you create a rapport ,sessions are filled with good energy and have a better flow . # 3. Safety of a spotter- Getting that extra rep or set can be daunting if you have a heavy bar hovering over your chest. Several times I have walked into an empty gym to see a lone trainer being crushed on the bench press ğŸ¤• HEEELP!!! # 4. Competition- As humans we are naturally quite competitive, if your having an off day and your partner is on point ,the energy they provide will push you to train harder than you normally would that day. # 5. Banter- training needs to have an element of fun for you to be consistent .Committing to a 12 week "transformation" program is fine but you need to be consistent after that.If you are enjoying your sessions you are more likely to make it part of your lifestyle. # I have had literally hundreds of training partners over the years all have helped me in different ways. So find yourself the right team and make exercise a regular part of your life. 13. Make it sociable â€œKeeping on top of your fitness doesnâ€™t have to be a chore. If you go to the gym with your friends a couple of times a week, why not grab a drink afterwards every now and again? Youâ€™ve got to be kind to yourself.â€
14. Watch the booze â€œBeer is dead calories. You go out on a Friday, before you know it youâ€™ve drunk 4 beers and thatâ€™s 1,000 calories. Youâ€™ve got to burn through that before you burn through your food before you burn through body fat, so if youâ€™re looking to burn fat, steer clear of the lager.
"A glass of red wine â€“ which is full of antioxidants â€“ before you go to bed, thatâ€™s great. But the binge-drinking can be a problem.â€
Watch | How to get rid of your beer belly 01:49 15. Limit your carbs â€œYour metabolism slows as you get older so you havenâ€™t got the same ability to eat carbs without putting a bit of weight on. Iâ€™m not saying donâ€™t eat carbs, Iâ€™m just saying be aware of them. You can still get energy from fats and protein but youâ€™ve just got to be aware of your carbs after forty.â€
16. Drink more water â€œYouâ€™ve got to stay hydrated. The bodyâ€™s 70pc water so if you donâ€™t drink enough you wonâ€™t be working efficiently. Teas and coffees dehydrate you so donâ€™t fall into the trap of consuming all of your water intake through hot drinksâ€.
17. Get 7 to 8 hours sleep â€œSleep is when you recover and most middle-aged people are chronically tired. The trouble is, as you get older, your sleep can be a bit more broken so youâ€™ve just got to treasure it a little bit and wind down before you go to bed.â€
18. Get some black out curtains â€œMake sure your bedroom is a place to sleep. Donâ€™t just get black out curtains but turn off your phone and your tablet. LED screens can really diminish your quality of sleep.â€
19. Meditate â€œAt night your brain is racing, youâ€™re thinking about work tomorrow and little tasks that you have to do. Meditation is about getting yourself in a calm space to help you sleep.â€
Watch | How to practice bedtime meditation 02:18 20. Take Epsom salt baths. â€œEpsom salt is rich in magnesium, which is proven to relax people when stressed. Itâ€™s best absorbed through the skin. I often take Epsom salt baths in the evening before I meditate.â€
21. Eat organic foods â€œOrganic food just hasnâ€™t been tampered with so much. Itâ€™s more expensive but itâ€™s worth it.â€
22. Try to watch less TV â€œIâ€™m not saying cut out TV but you can get into a habit of zonking out. Iâ€™ve worked with people in the past who would come in from work, theyâ€™d open a beer and theyâ€™d just sit there for four hours. Easy to do.
"Those hours are the hours you should be prioritising exercise.â€
23. Eat more protein â€œWhen most people write down what theyâ€™ve eaten for three days, its 80pc carbs. Protein helps your body repair, itâ€™s what your body really needs. As carnivores, we need protein in every meal.â€
Steak, glorious steak 24. Stay away from sweeteners â€œItâ€™s alright thinking, oh Iâ€™m eating a sweetener, itâ€™s not really sugar, but youâ€™re still getting an insulin kick which is not great. You should aim to keep your insulin level stable; sweeteners create imbalance.â€
25. Increase your fibre. â€œPack your diet with vegetables, you canâ€™t have too many.â€
26. Watch the dairy â€œ70pc of us canâ€™t digest dairy products. Itâ€™s the pasteurisation process thatâ€™s the killer. Youâ€™re better drinking almond milk than you are drinking milk.â€
27. Green tea â€œGreen tea is filled with antioxidants and can bolster fat loss. Itâ€™s also far less caffeinated than breakfast tea as well as being dairy-free.
"If you have multiple cups of tea a day, why not swap one of your cups of tea a day for a mug of green tea. Youâ€™d be surprised at how quickly you can break old habits.â€
28. Increase smart fats. â€œSmart fats, like those found in avocado and coconut oil, are a bit more essential as you get older.â€
29. Be sensible with desserts â€œThe older generation have often been brought up to always have dessert and thatâ€™s the dish that can really rack the calories up. Greek yoghurt is a good substitute.â€
Start the day with a high protein smart fat breakfast - better for your energy and stable blood sugar, so less cravings! #over40fitness pic.twitter.com/XHMNJXwDBd 
â€” James Crossley (@MrJamesCrossley) January 10, 2017 30. Eat off a smaller plate â€œWeâ€™ve all been brought up to finish our plate â€“ no leaving the table before you've finished.
S erve your dinner on a smaller plate and youâ€™ll trick your brain into thinking youâ€™ve eaten a full meal.â€
31. Use apple cider vinegar as dressing â€œItâ€™s very good at breaking down fats and has been proven to lower blood-sugar levels.
"Get rid of your caesar dressing and replace it with apple cider vinegar.â€
32. Try fasted cardio â€œIf you go for a run first thing in the morning then thereâ€™s nothing in you. So have a black coffee, get the metabolism going, and then set off. Youâ€™ll be in a fat burning-zone within about four minutes.
"Itâ€™s all about kickstarting the fat-burning process.â€
33. Take the stairs instead of the lift â€œYou can always opt out of a lift or escalator. Little changes like this make all the difference.â€
34. Get off a train stop early â€œSet off ten minutes earlier and enjoy the walk. Again, this is a simple choice you can make every day that, over a long period of time, will make a big difference.â€
35. Take up yoga â€œEspecially when youâ€™re over 40, you start getting very tight, lower-back muscles. I meet middle-aged people whose muscles are so tight that they can barely reach down to tie their shoelaces.
"Yoga is great for mobility. I work out four days a work and always go to a yoga class once a week.
36. Add supplements â€œYou think youâ€™re getting loads of vitamins with your food but itâ€™s often been heavily processed. Itâ€™s just a means of insurance. I take Omega 3, zinc for vitality and magnesium to help my sleep.â€
37. Take a probiotic â€œItâ€™s not about what you eat, itâ€™s about what you absorb. Many peopleâ€™s gut health isnâ€™t great just from years of an abusive lifestyle. I suffer from leaky gut, which means that a lot of the protein I eat often goes unprocessed and leaks out of my gut. Probiotics help with the digestion process.â€
38. Go swimming â€œSwimming is just a good, low impact form of exercise. If you have joint issues, which a lot of people do, swimming is a good choice. Also with swimming you donâ€™t have to get your heart rate as high to get in the fat-burning zone.â€
39. Use a foam roller â€œA foam roller is the one item of gym equipment I recommend everyone invests in. The fascia can get very tight around your lower-back muscles which restricts movement. A foam roller can really loosen this up. I bought one for my dad recently and he uses it all the time.â€
40. Work postural muscles â€œAs a personal trainer, office workers are instantly recognizable by their posture. Bad posture usually means a tight chest so mobility work such as opening the chest with exercise bands is good. Deadlifts, face pulls and planks all work to strengthen the upper back muscles so itâ€™s worth trying these out too.â€
